awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Paving the way to the commercialization of additives that boost battery performance
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnership for Innovation – Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project comes from the development of additives that provide an immediate boost in battery capacity without introducing any changes to their manufacturing scheme. The lack of affordable higher-capacity batteries is recognized as a barrier to the broad utilization of, for instance, electric vehicles and renewable energy sources. Improved batteries are needed to support a transition to a greener and more sustainable society. The development of additives that can be easily integrated in current battery designs will facilitate their implementation and future commercialization, giving them a crucial advantage at a time when the battery market is both rapidly expanding and becoming increasingly competitive. This NSF PFI-TT grant will support technological validation and the development of prototypes for field-testing, both necessary step towards successful commercialization. The PI will leverage both the existing close collaboration with the Entrepreneurial Proof of Concept and Innovation Center (EPIC) and the presence of a large population of students from under-represented minorities at UCR Riverside, an accredited Hispanic Serving Institution, to provide unique training opportunities not only in science and engineering but also in entrepreneurship.

The proposed project will target additives based on silicon, which, while having much higher lithiation capacity than broadly utilized graphite, has yet to be adopted by battery manufacturers on a large scale. This is due to both technical (silicon alone has poor stability over many charge-discharge cycles) and economic (silicon can be made stable but this requires complex designs) issues. This project will overcome these limitations. A simple, single-stage carbon coating step enables the integration of silicon powders into graphite-dominant anodes. Careful control of the process parameters allows realizing a high-quality carbon coating, which is crucial for the successful utilization of the additives. By developing a “drop-in” additive, this technology enables an increase in battery capacity without requiring any capital intensive investment for the battery manufacturers. As part of this project, this core technology will be advanced and the results in terms of capacity improvement and cycle stability will be validated by independent testing facilities. By the completion of this project, battery prototypes that incorporate silicon-based additives will be field-tested under real-life conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Regents of the University of California

por.por_cntn:
This PFI-TT project aims at developing a high-capacity anode material that increases the energy density of Li-ion batteries without requiring any change to the current battery production process. The compound is based on silicon and carbon, i.e. earth abundant and sustainable materials.

The development of more energy-dense Li-ion batteries is widely considered as a requirement for the transition of our fossil-fuel based economy to a more sustainable zero-emission society, enabling a more efficient utilization of intermittent renewable sources and the production of electric vehicles that can economically compete with combustion engine cars. The incremental improvements of the storage capacity achieved by large battery manufacturers are not sufficient to satisfy the more rapidly growing customer demand for advance energy storage technologies. 

The outcome of the proposed activity is the development of a novel Li-ion battery prototype which effectively incorporates silicon into its formulation. The battery raw material suppliers and the drone market are considered the most promising  points of entry to the market for the proposed innovation, as highlited by the market research performed during the NSF I-CorpsTM programs by the team of Professor Mangolini.

Intellectual merit

The main obstacle to overcome for the introduction of silicon in Li-ion batteries is the instability of the material upon lithiation, causing rapid capacity fading and poor coulombic efficiency. This project has addressed these issues by developing a cost-effective and large-volume fabrication protocol for the production of silicon-carbon battery materials. The production approach will be based on a proprietary Chemical Vapor Deposition -CVD- process developed by the Mangolini?s group, that achieves the growth of highly graphitic carbon layers onto the surface of silicon nanoparticles. The process purposely deploys an inexpensive carbon precursor to enable a low processing cost. A second goal of the proposed plan is the development of a strategy for the utilization of this technology into industrial battery manufacturing. This project aims at developing a ?drop-in? additive that can be integrated into the established graphite electrode fabrication process while boosting the storage capacity of the anode beyond the state-of-the-art. This strategy is simple, cost-effective and eliminates the need for extensive capital investments for the battery manufactures.

Broader Impacts

The development of a battery prototype which incorporates the drop-in additive developed in the PI?s research group will provide crucially important validation, necessary to transition this project towards further scale-up and commercialization. The successful development of this battery technology will give an important advantage to various US battery manufacturer at a time when the global market for batteries is both expanding and becoming increasingly competitive. From a societal point of view, there is a dire need for effective energy storage technologies, since these will help transitioning towards a greener and more sustainable economy. In addition, this project will be crucial at training the next generation of scientist, engineers and entrepreneurs. A variety of training and mentoring programs, organized by the Entrepreneurial Proof of Concept and Innovation Center (EPIC) at UC Riverside and the Excite startup incubator in Riverside, will be completed to aid the preparation of the next generation of leaders in innovation and entrepreneurship. In addition, UC Riverside is an accredited Hispanic Serving Institution which is already recognized as a leader in the education of students from underrepresented and disadvantaged backgrounds. UC Riverside is therefore uniquely positioned to also expand the participation of women and other underrepresented groups in innovation and entrepreneurship.

 


Last Modified: 06/19/2023
Modified by: Lorenzo Mangolini
